Title: Introduction
SubText1:
Welcome to the General William Jenkins Worth Monument.  Located in Manhattan at the intersections of Broadway,
Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, I was drawn to this site because I
have lived and worked within walking distance of it for thirty-plus years but
discovered (as part of our team’s initial research) that it is one of only two
public memorials in New York City that contain the actual remains of the
person.  [The second is President Grant’s
Tomb in upper Manhattan.]
SubText2: Having ignored the site for so long, I spent an afternoon watching it and noticed that ignoring the monument was the dominant behavior of almost all the people who passed by.
SubText3: That experience led me to ask why? What was it about the site made it almost disappear into the streetscape? And why had the memory of the man himself seemingly faded from common knowledge?

SubText1: Memorials in general, and war memorials in particular, are highly social publicly-curated creations that endeavor to fix in time a way of thinking about a person or event.  War memorials are both a way to commemorate a conflict and a way to remember the people involved in that conflict.
SubText2: In modern times, they often emphasize the common person who served and died as a result of the conflict; consider the Vietnam Memorial in Washington, DC [https://www.nps.gov/vive/index.htm] with its V-shaped black granite wall that lists the names of the dead.  But in ancient times, these memorials were more likely to be victory celebrations around successful military campaigns; consider the Arch of Constantine in Rome [https://www.thebyzantinelegacy.com/constantine-arch], which was built in 312 A.D. to commemorate that Roman emperor’s victory “over Maxentius at the Milvian Bridge in 312 as well as to celebrate his decennalia” (Britannica).
SubText3:
The Worth Memorial is meant to remember the man
but is dominated by the names of places where he fought, and these places are directly
tied to the expansion of the United States into Florida and Mexico in the mid-1800.

Title: About General William Jenkins Worth - A Brief Biography
Text Box: William Jenkins Worth was born in Hudson, New York on March 1st, 1794.  He spent his entire adult life serving in the U.S. Army, rising by battle commission until he reached the highest rank of Major General.  He served as Commandant of Cadets at West Point, distinguished himself in the War of 1812, the war against the Seminole nation, and the war against Mexico.  While serving as the Army Commander of the Department of Texas, he succumbed to Cholera on May 7th, 1849.

Title: Mexican War of 1846-1848
SubText1:
Worth’s victories in the Mexican War of 1846-1848 made him famous during his lifetime. 
In 1845, President James Polk ordered Brevet Brigadier General Zachary Taylor to defend the Texas territories against threats from Mexico.  General Worth soon joined him.
SubText2: Worth commanded at the Battle of Monterey, and he is credited as being the first American to make an amphibious landing, when he jumped from his boat during the attack on Veracruz.  When Mexico City fell, Worth climbed to the top of the National Palace and replaced the Mexican flag with the Stars and Stripes.
SubText3: Handsome, a superb horseman, and consider by many to be one of the most brilliant officers in the army, had Worth lived, his exploits might have propelled him as a presidential candidate on the Democratic ticket in 1852.

Title: Competition in the Ranks
SubText1:
The battle of Monterey was the high-water mark of his military career.  After Monterey,
Worth was transferred from General Zachary Taylor’s command to that of General Winfield
Scott.  Scott craved the limelight, leading to conflict with his subordinates.  A contemporary satire casts Scott as squelching
the ambition of Zachary Taylor, following his successes, by dumping a bowl of soup on Taylor’s head.
SubText2:
Worth and other officers sided with Taylor, leading
to “a rancorous quarrel …Charges were preferred …This quarrel broke up a long friendship between Worth and Scott” (Wallace).  In late 1848, Scott to assign him to the command of the Military Departments of Texas and New Mexico.  This was a de facto political exile.
SubText3: In early 1849, his old regiment, the 8th Infantry, arrived at San Antonio and they brought cholera. Worth succumbed to the deadly bacterium in May.

Title: Manifest Destiny
Text Box: This was the era that was defined by "Manifest Destiny", a belief that the United States was destined to expand its dominion across the continent.  Worth was a champion of that mindset.  What follows is an excerpt from a letter he wrote to William Learned Marcy, then the U.S. Secretary of War, following the capture of Mexico City in 1847:
SubText1:
"That our race is finally destined to overrun this whole continent is too obvious to need proof. Like an axiom in
mathematics, it is only necessary to state the proposition to ensure belief: 
and we may state it thus:
SubText2:
Put two distinct races in juxtaposition, one more  powerful and superior in civilization, and it will absorb the inferior.  

The most that can be said in opposition to this is that we are somewhat premature, perhaps half a century.  But what is half a century in the affairs of a nation like ours, thoroughly imbued with the progressive spirit. A mere point, which, like a point in mathematics, should not enter into the solution of the great problem."
SubText3: Worth was prescient.  Over the course of the nineteenth century the country known as the United State of America expanded beyond its original colonial footprint to span the continent.

Title: Gilded Age
Text Box: The powerbrokers of New York City's Gilded Age were drivers of this expansion. For example,
SubText1:
· The financier John Pierpont Morgan drove industrial consolidation, 
· Andrew Carnegie led the expansion of the steel industry,
· Cornelius Vanderbilt built railroad and shipping lines that transformed the geography of the continent, 
· John D. Rockefeller revolutionized the petroleum industry,
SubText2: And they all lived within shooting distance of Madison Square when Worth died.
SubText3: A nuanced and mindful examination of Manifest Destiny, American Exceptionalism, and their dark legacies is beyond the scope of this endeavor.  However, this proposition seems obvious: The military actions of soldiers like Worth made the fortunes of the Gilded Age possible.  And by memorializing this man, the powers were writing history the way they desired it to be remembered.

Title: Preparations
SubText1: My research did not uncover who championed the memorial behind the scenes.  The official recommendation came from the Board of Aldermen of the Common Council... what we would now call the City Council ...and was passed by unanimous consent in 1848.
SubText2: It took years to plan and build the monument (much to the consternation of the General’s family).  During this time, the General's remains layin a vault at Green-wood cemetery in Brooklyn.

Title: The Dedication Ceremony
Text Box:
When the laying-in ceremony took place, on November 25th, 1857, the entire city turned out.  The funeral procession started at City Hall,
where Worth had lain in state.  The governor of New York led four brigades of militia, in full dress uniform, up Broadway and then Fifth Avenue.
SubText1:
Each brigade consisted of four regiments of infantry, cavalry, and light artillery, with one brass band to each
regiment.  [Yes, sixteen brass bands!]  Then came the General’s horse, in its battle gear, led riderless.  Finally, the
carriage with the general’s casket, which was drawn by four black stallions in silvered harness.
SubText2: Immediately behind were twenty carriages carrying the general’s family and friends, and assorted Tammany Society politicians.  And then came the common folks and retired soldiers, many of whom had served under Worth’s command.
SubText3: The day was biting cold.  When the procession made its way to the actual monument, the crowd was dispersed save for 71st Regiment.  Various relics in a copper box were placed in the cornerstone, along with the remains of the man himself.  The observances concluded with a Masonic ritual and the firing of three volleys by the 71st.

Title: Fernando Wood
Text Box: Fernando Wood, the mayor of New York, gave a long and bombastic eulogy that was not particularly well-received.  However, his closing statement explains what they hoped the memorial would accomplish:
SubText1: “The youth of our country, passing and repassing this monument, will hereafter pause to peruse the record engraved thereon, of the virtue, service, and fame, of a man whose life presents a beautiful illustration of the institutions of our country, having raised himself from civil life to the highest rank know in the army; and every gradation in the chain of his elevation having been due to the fidelity of his adherence to professional duty.”
SubText2: The historian, Edward Wallace, who wrote the only comprehensive biography of Worth, gave Wood some cover.  Here is a quote from his 1948 dissertation:
SubText3:
“It is possible that his honor was under a considerable nervous strain for the Metropolitan Police Force created by the Republican state legislature was at the time engaged in a series of brawls and fisticuffs with the municipal police controlled by the city administration, and, shortly before, there had been a regular knock-down and drag-out fight in the City Hall.” 

It is a reminder of how turbulent the times were!

Title: The Monument Itself
SubText1: Staged in a triangle of cement, when standing before the monument, it is huge.  Fenced by cast-iron verticals that resemble long-swords, the monument is a 51-foot obelisk of bronze and granite.  A stark needle of stone, with plaques that announce the man's principal battles, and a relief of the General himself astride his horse with sword held high.
SubText2: Above the relief is a bronze grouping of objects referred to as a "trophy".  There are swords and flags, shields, and cannons, and an eagle with a snake in its month.  These elements were typical of the time and chosen to convey that courage, glory, and victory are worthy aims.

Title: Map of 1811
SubText1: Today, the area surrounding the monument is dominated by tall buildings, with Madison Park the only bit of greenery for blocks in any direction, but when the monument was constructed, the landscape was very different.
SubText2: As laid down on the Commissioners' Map of 1811... that foundational plan which created the current street grid of Manhattan... a military Parade Ground was to exist from 23rd to 34th Streets, bounded on the east by the Eastern Post-Road (now Madison Avenue) and on the west by the Bloomingdale Road (now Broadway), and was largely common land belonging to the city.
SubText3: This parade ground included barracks and an armory.  There was also a Potter's Field that has been opened in 1794.

Title: Madison Roadhouse
Text Box: In the 1830s, the area around Madison Square was considered so remote that Corporal Thompson’s Roadhouse (also known as Madison Cottage) at 23rd Street, the last stop for stagecoaches to and from the city, was still open for business. (Blecher)

Title: Madison Park
SubText1: However, as the city expanded, the plan was changed.  The Potter's Field was displaced.  The barracks were moved further uptown and, in 1837, the Parade Ground was reduced to the dimensions of the present Madison Square Park.
SubText2: Named after President James Madison, it was formally opened as a park in June 1847. The wealthy of society then migrated to Madison Square, so that from 1853 and until after the Civil War, Madison Square was the social center of the city.

Title: The Changing City
Text Box:
Once the ceremony concluded, the monument and Worth fade from public view.  With the creation of Central Park, the wealthy continue their migrations uptown and the
area around Madison Square Park becomes more commercial.  The mansions are supplanted by hotels and office buildings.

Title: Water!
SubText1: As living memory fades, monuments to past are often supplanted for the newest fashion.  I began to wonder why this monument, housed on what is arguably some of the most valuable real estate in the world, had been permitted to remain?
SubTitle2: The answer presented itself in one word: water.
SubText2: As New York grew, so did its people’s thirst.  The local water sources were not enough, and by the early 1800s, plans to funnel water from Westchester and later the Catskills, had been developed.  The city dug deep tunnels in the bedrock to bring fresh water into the five boroughs.
SubText3: To save time and money, the land used to dig the Catskill water tunnels was almost completely owned by the City.  There were fourteen shafts sunk on Manhattan island and the shaft that serves the area around Madison Park is right under the Worth Monument!

Title: Renovations
Text Box: The water project was completed in 1911 and augmented in the 1940s.  It was this augmentation that brought the funerial bronze shed that now sits on the north side of the monument.
SubText1: There have been several renovations of the monument since its original construction.
SubText2: In 1987, the City’s “Adopt a Monument” initiative brought private money to its repair. And in 1995, a major restoration was completed through that same program.
